As I understand, the direction of the angular momentum vector was chosen arbitrarily. In other words, we could have made it the left hand rule. It is just a way to describe rotation easily. I feel like this description is trying to say this phenomenon is caused by outward angular momentum, but that's just a concept we invented.

To understand the real reason you can think of the top of the wheel as a point. With no spinning, that point will travel outward, pivoting around the string vertically. But this point is moving around the wheel, so the side of the wheel that the top rotates towards gets pushed out. In the same way, the bottom of the wheel is trying to travel inwards, so the other side of the wheel gets pushed inward. So if you think about it, it's just like applying an outward force to the left of the wheel, and an inward force to the right of the wheel, or vise versa. That's what causes the horizontal rotation instead of the vertical rotation.

The spinning wheel resists change in direction. Because gravity is pulling down on the wheel the top of the wheel is pushed in a vector away from the contact point, while the bottom of the wheel is pushed toward the contact point, on a horizontal axis.

This force does not immediately pivot the wheel on this axis, however, because of the resistance of change. Now, when the top of the wheel that has accumulated force away from the contact reaches the horizontal axis it is forced to move now toward the contact point, 180⁰ from its current saved up vector. Being pushed now on both sides the forces apply a squeezing force of the metal, which will not squeeze. So, theforces have to reconcile, with the greater force pushing away and the lesser force, being closer to the point
of horizontal rotation, pushing towards the point of contact. Big vector away minus smaller vector toward is a net movement away, which turns the wheel away.

On the bottom side the opposite takes place with a net result of spinning on the vertical axis.

This is the typical gobbledygook professors teach their glassy eyed, dazed students all the time. This kind of explanation GUARANTEES the student will NOT understand the concept in any meaningful way. First of all I challenge anyone, after watching this video, to explain angular momentum. Further, vectors don't push vectors, they are mathematical constructs not physical bodies subject to force. The same is true of the so-called torque vector.

I am a retired physics instructor with 33 years experience teaching physics at about every level conceivable, from entry level survey classes to freshman physics with calculus. I have NEVER introduced this concept this way, and certainly not to an audience of non-scientists such as those watching YouTube. Yes, once the students understand the REAL physics of what is happening, then I introduce angular momentum and torque.

Honestly, how many of you REALLY understand what is actually happening at a level where you could explain it to someone else?

Based on my experience, and the critique above, I had to give this video a thumbs down. I am disappointed, I thought he would do a better job teaching this at a level where the average person could come away saying, "NOW, I understand!"

First, I am going to make a bold controversial statement. The angular momentum and torque vectors do not exist in reality, they are mathematical constructs. Prove it you say! Okay, that is very easy. You saw him using his right hand, curling his fingers and pointing to show the two vectors. But I can do exactly the same thing with my left hand and get exactly the same results. The choice of hands is arbitrary. So what? If the vectors represented real quantities, we could not reverse them and get the same result. If you apply a force in a given direction the force vector represent that force, which points in the direction of the force. Angular momentum and torque are real, but the vectors we use to represent them are mathematical constructs.

So why do we teach concepts using constructs that are not real? Because they work, and make it easy to analyze real world scenarios, but they sacrifice understanding. So here is a simple explanation of what is happening using simple Newtonian concepts that a fifth grader could understand.

Let's use his demonstration for the lesson.

1) When the orange section is at the top of the wheel it is moving toward him, it has momentum. The wheel is suspended so that it experiences a force at the orange spot directed to his right, as a result of the torque. In other words, if he lets go of the stationary wheel the top will fall to his right toward you the viewer, or clockwise from his perspective. If the orange section is moving toward him and a force pushes toward his right it will turn to the right, turning the entire wheel. This will happen all along the top half of the wheel.

Try this. Hold your right hand in front of your face with your thumb up and your fingers pointing toward your face. Now slowly move your hand toward your face like the top of the wheel. Use your left hand to push your moving hand to the right and it will rotate toward the right. If this were the wheel it would rotate so the side closer to you moved toward the right while the opposite side moved to the left., or counterclockwise looking down on it from the top.

2) Now let's analyze the bottom half of the wheel where the orange section is moving away from him. In this case the force on the orange section will be toward his left. The orange section moving away from him turns to the left so the section closer to him once again rotates toward his right or counterclockwise as viewed from above.

This time hold your left hand about belly button level and point your fingers away from you. Slowly move you hand away from you and push it toward the left with your right hand. Of course, it turns left. If this were the wheel the side closer to you would rotate to the right while the opposite side rotated left, exactly the same rotation as before.

The combined forces would rotate the wheel so the side closer to him rotates right, while the opposite side rotate left, or counterclockwise as viewed downward from above.

This is what is actually happening physically, a simple case of force changing the direction of moving mass. While this is a simple explanation of what is happening, it would require calculations for a huge number of sections, and the results would then have to be added together. It is easier to define and use the mathematical constructs, angular momentum vector, and torque vector to do the calculations even though you sacrifice an understanding of the underlying physical process.

Terrible way to explain a gyroscope, a better way is to use the example of a pendulum being like a single point on a wheel, and as it passes you, you push it, changing its direction, if every other time it passes, so every time from the right to the left for example, you'll find you have to rotate around with it, to stay at its side.

This example of a pendulum can be considered as a point on a wheel.

Instead of using angular momentum to justify such behavior, can we state the following ? :
View the setup with the edge of the wheel facing you.
If we consider torque about the point of suspension of the wheel it equals the weight of the wheel times the distance from the point of suspension (assuming a perfect 90° angle between the wheel and the rod), whose vector points toward you. Call this vector V1. If we rotate the wheel, we are producing a torque whose vector's direction is perpendicular to V1. Call this V2. However since V1 and V2 are taken from different reference points i.e. come from two different axes of rotation, the resultant vector describes a kind of combination of both rotations. If V2 is much larger in magnitude that V1, then the wheel may not experience a downward rotation, but obviously a rotation about its centre and rotate sideways as the vector is inclined to the wheel.

This is my understanding of the phenomena. Starting with a rotational momentum of the spinning wheel and adding gravity, a new momentum arises on the wheel in conjunction with the initial. Adding these two momenta vectors together, in order for the overall angular momentum to remain conserved, the new angular momentum points in a direction of which the wheel’s angular position is turned some angular displacement away from the initial position, (in other words, it rotated). Because of this new position, there is an even newer angular momentum in conjunction with this momentum from the new torque and axis of rotation which results in yet again another angular momentum. This continues on until friction forces cause the wheel to stop spinning.

A lot of things in physics are vectors and reference frames. The precession motion is relevant to all spinning objects, be it an helicopter shaft, aeroplane propeller or the earth itself. It arises from the centrifugal force experienced by the spinning objects around an axis especially with high angular velocity. The lateral component of this force ``imagine the spherical coordinate frame`` incorporates the ``harmonic`` force whose torque causing the precesion of the object. If you don't understand this explanation, think of it like this:
Any one point on the edge of the wheel has momentum in it's current direction, ok? Let's say it has the momentum value of 100.
Now imagine pushing that point towards the rope, that is, perpendicular to the direction the wheel is spinning.
Push with a force of 1.
Now, the point has a momentum 100 in one direction and 1 in another.
Add these together and you get a momentum of 100 + x in a slightly tilted direction.
The path that the point will now take to go around the wheel will now be inclined from the original path. Read that until you get it.
The point at which the point will be farthest from the original point's trajectory is roughly 90 degrees from where the force was applied.
Therefore, the force will push up at 90 degrees and you get gyroscopic precession.

Precession. When a force, Torque is applied to a Gyroscope, the force effect precesses 90* in the direction of the rotation. Eg. When riding a bicycle, hands free, when I bank left, the the force applied at the top of the rim, pushing it left, precesses forward by 90* in the direction of the rotation of the wheel, and turns the wheel Left. ie The Torque on top of the rim, instead of left tilt, it gives left Yaw. That is precession.

The right-hand rule for vectors associated with rotation is simply a convention. The convention could just as easily have been a "left hand rule", and with the logic presented in this video, the explanation is no longer consistent (with the logic presented in this video, a left-hand rule would have resulted in the bicycle wheel precessing in the other direction).
From my understanding, angular momenta are conceptual one-directional axes that exist in three dimensional space. They do not originate from points in space and go outward from those points; they are axes. With this understanding, the explanation present in this video is incorrect.

Still I could never find out why a wheel precesses the direction it does until i saw a video explaining it. As the wheel wants to rotate it's axis vertically due to the gravity, it is creating an angular momentum about the vertical axis just by the act of tilting. So in other words, tilting causes an increase in angular momentum about the vertical axis. But since action = opposite reaction, the wheel itself is subject to a torque in the opposite direction hence the precession. In other words, the wheel precesses in the counter direction you are making it spin in by the act of tilting it.

For others who also are questioning why the right-hand-rule exists like I was, here's a post I just made. Copy/paste since a lot of people ignore comment-thread replies.




Use a left-hand rule and visualize this wheel-spinning experiment. The result will be the exact same.

The right-hand-rule is just a tool to help keep you consistent. All that matters is "perpendicular". Left-hand, or right-hand. Right-hand-rule is just conventional.

If you're doing your /own/ work, for your own uses, you can use a "left-hand-rule" and the result is the same.

Imagine the "vectors". One vector is pointing to you, the other vector by the string is pointing to your right. Add them together and you get a slightly counter-clockwise (Looking from above) spin.

Left-hand-rule?

The vector would be pointing behind, or away from you, and the string vector would be pointing left. Add those two together and, again, you get a counter-clockwise (Looking from above) spin.

What matters isn't right-hand or left-hand, it's just "perpendicular", and "consistent". (IE, use right-hand or left-hand for the entire calculation and don't switch between the two half-way).

The explanation that makes the most sense to me is to think about it in terms of inertia. If you let the wheel drop without spinning, a piece of mass on the top half of the wheel  (12 o'clock position) wants to moves away from the rope as it swings down. However, if the wheel is turning, the piece of mass at the 12 O'clock position is now at the 9 O'clock position but, due to inertia, it still has velocity pulling it away from the rope which translates to a processional velocity around the rope.

The right-hand rule in fact does not have anything special that the left-hand rule doesn't. The right-hand rule applies only because of conventional definitions, i.e. we usually work in a right-handed system (x-y-z-axis aligned according to a right-hand rules). This makes the vector-product that is used in the definition of angular momentum/torque (e.g. L=r x p) also adhere to a right-hand rule. This basically boils down to everything being right-handed. (in fact also in electricity: F=q(v x B))

When it comes to electricity, the right hand rule is used for positive particles, where as there actually is a left hand rule for negative particles, such as electrons. When it comes to this video, I have no idea :)

Short answer: Because we defined it that way. Long answer: Because we defined angular velocity to use the vector cross product: w = r x v, read the w as a lowercase Greek omega. With angular velocity, you can find angular momentum, L, with this: L = r x mv = r x p. With that understanding, you must also understand that where force is the rate of change of momentum, torque is the rate of change of angular momentum. Then, we can prove that T = r x F. OR: [Angular Version] = r x [Normal Version]
What ?

Without angular momentum: swing a weight in a vertical circle by your right side, going backwards over the top and forwards under the bottom  As the weight goes over the top, bap it to the right.  The next circle goes through the same bap point, but the plane of the circle is moved left in front and right in back.

The reason it's unintuitive is that we intuit that force changes position.  Wrong. It changes velocity, and the difference matters in a gyroscope.

The reason the Torque is in the direction of his thumb is a because of something that you do when multiplying vectors called "Cross product". When two vectors are multiplied the result is a new vector that is perpendicular to the two vectors. If you imagine force on the y- axis and radius on the x axis the only way to make a vector perpendicular is for it to be on the z axis. The magnitude of the new vector is the area between the two vectors. In this case its only Length*Width or F*r

right/left was arbitrarily decided upon by scientists long ago. You could use a "left hand rule" (consistently throughout the explanation), and the result will be exactly the same. Since angular momentum and torque are both vectors, you need a direction for them. They line up along an axis of rotation. Since the axis extends to infinity in two directions (senses is the proper term, not directions), you need to be able to tell the two directions apart, thus right and left.
